\usepackage{babel}
\begin{document}
\begin{lyxcode}
\textbf{A~model~with~two~consumption~goods,~one~perishable~and~one~durable}

The~consumer's~problem~in~a~general~equilibrium~setup~can~be~described~by

$\max_{c,i,x}\mathbb{E}_{0}\sum_{t=0}^{\infty}\beta^{t}\bigg\{\frac{[c_{t}^{\alpha}d_{t}^{1-\alpha}]^{1-\gamma}}{1-\gamma}\bigg\}$

$\text{\text{s.t. \ensuremath{\ensuremath{\ensuremath{c_{t}+p_{t}(1}-\theta_{t})x_{t}+i_{t}}\leq(1-\tau_{H})w_{t}+(1-\tau_{K})r_{t}k_{t}+\delta_{K}\tau_{K}k_{t}+T_{t}}.}}$

Here~$x_{t}$~is~the~investment~in~durables,~and~$i_{t}$~the~investment~in~capital.The~transfer~$T_{t}$~satisfies~the~balanced~budget~constraint.~The~price~of~capital~is~normalized~to~1.~The~Lagrangian,~after~substituting~in~the~laws~of~motion~for~durables~and~capital,~is

$\mathcal{L}=\mathbb{E}_{0}\sum_{t=0}^{\infty}\beta^{t}\bigg\{\frac{[c_{t}^{\alpha}d_{t}^{1-\alpha}]^{1-\gamma}}{1-\gamma}\bigg\}+\sum_{t}\lambda_{t}\bigg[(1-\tau_{H})w_{t}+(1-\tau_{K})r_{t}k_{t}+\delta_{K}\tau_{K}k_{t}+T_{t}-(k_{t+1}-(1-\delta_{K})k_{t})-p_{t}(1-\theta_{t})(d_{t+1}-(1-\delta)d_{t})-c_{t}\bigg]$

Then~take~relevant~FOCs:

$\bigg[c_{t}\bigg]\qquad\qquad\qquad\beta^{t}\big[c_{t}^{\alpha}d_{t}^{1-\alpha}\big]^{-\gamma}\alpha c_{t}^{\alpha-1}d_{t}^{1-\alpha}=\lambda_{t}$

$\bigg[c_{t+1}\bigg]\qquad\qquad\qquad\beta^{t+1}\big[c_{t+1}^{\alpha}d_{t+1}^{1-\alpha}\big]^{-\gamma}\alpha c_{t+1}^{\alpha-1}d_{t+1}^{1-\alpha}=\lambda_{t+1}$

$\bigg[d_{t+1}\bigg]\qquad\qquad\qquad\beta^{t+1}\big[c_{t+1}^{\alpha}d_{t+1}^{1-\alpha}\big]^{-\gamma}(1-\alpha)c_{t+1}^{\alpha}d_{t+1}^{-\alpha}+p_{t+1}(1-\theta_{t+1})(1-\delta)\lambda_{t+1}=p_{t}(1-\theta_{t})\lambda_{t}$

$\bigg[k_{t+1}\bigg]\qquad\qquad\qquad\bigg[(1-\tau_{K})r_{t+1}+\delta_{K}\tau_{K}+(1-\delta_{K})\bigg]\lambda_{t+1}=\lambda_{t}\Rightarrow\Delta^{K}\lambda_{t+1}=\lambda_{t}$~

$\Delta^{K}$~corresponds~to~discountK~in~the~code.~Substitute~$\big[k_{t+1}]$~into~$\big[d_{t+1}]$~to~get~

$\beta^{t+1}\big[c_{t+1}^{\alpha}d_{t+1}^{1-\alpha}\big]^{-\gamma}(1-\alpha)c_{t+1}^{\alpha}d_{t+1}^{-\alpha}=\lambda_{t+1}\bigg[p_{t}(1-\theta_{t})\Delta^{K}-p_{t+1}(1-\theta_{t+1})(1-\delta)\bigg]$

Substitute~in~$[c_{t+1}]$~to~get

$\frac{1-\alpha}{\alpha}\bigg(\frac{c_{t+1}}{d_{t+1}}\bigg)^{\alpha}\bigg(\frac{c_{t+1}}{d_{t+1}}\bigg)^{1-\alpha}=\frac{1-\alpha}{\alpha}\frac{c_{t+1}}{d_{t+1}}=p_{t}(1-\theta_{t})\Delta^{K}-p_{t+1}(1-\theta_{t+1})(1-\delta)$

or

$d_{t+1}=\frac{1-\alpha}{\alpha}\bigg\{ c_{t+1}/\big[p_{t}(1-\theta_{t})\Delta^{K}-p_{t+1}(1-\theta_{t+1})(1-\delta)\big]\bigg\}$.

Instead,~if~we~solve~for~$\lambda_{t}$~in~$\big[k_{t+1}]$,then~divide~$[c_{t}]$~from~$\big[c_{t+1}]$,~the~result~is

$\beta\frac{\big[c_{t+1}^{\alpha}d_{t+1}^{1-\alpha}\big]^{-\gamma}}{\big[c_{t}^{\alpha}d_{t}^{1-\alpha}\big]^{-\gamma}}\bigg(\frac{d_{t+1}}{c_{t+1}}\bigg)^{1-\alpha}\bigg(\frac{c_{t}}{d_{t}}\bigg)^{1-\alpha}=1/\Delta^{K}$

or

$\frac{d_{t}}{c_{t}}=\bigg\{\beta\frac{\big[c_{t+1}^{\alpha}d_{t+1}^{1-\alpha}\big]^{-\gamma}}{\big[c_{t}^{\alpha}d_{t}^{1-\alpha}\big]^{-\gamma}}\Delta^{K}\bigg\}^{\frac{1}{1-\alpha}}\bigg(\frac{d_{t+1}}{c_{t+1}}\bigg).$

$\bigg(\beta\Delta^{K}d_{t+1}^{-\gamma}\bigg[\frac{p_{t-1}(1-\theta_{t-1})\Delta_{-1}^{K}-p_{t}(1-\theta_{t})(1-\delta)}{p_{t}(1-\theta_{t})\Delta^{K}-p_{t+1}(1-\theta_{t+1})(1-\delta)}\bigg]^{1+\alpha(\gamma-1)}=d_{t}^{-\gamma}\bigg)$

All~the~other~equations~in~equilibrium~are~standard.



\textbf{A~model~with~one~durable~consumption~good}

Now~the~consumer's~utility~function~and~constraint~is

$\max_{i,x}\mathbb{E}_{0}\sum_{t=0}^{\infty}\beta^{t}\cdot\frac{d_{t}^{1-\gamma}}{1-\gamma}$

$\text{\text{s.t. \ensuremath{\ensuremath{\ensuremath{p_{t}(1}-\theta_{t})x_{t}+i_{t}}\leq(1-\tau_{H})w_{t}+(1-\tau_{K})r_{t}k_{t}+\delta_{K}\tau_{K}k_{t}+T_{t}}.}}$

The~Lagrangian~is~

$\mathcal{L}=\mathbb{E}_{0}\sum_{t=0}^{\infty}\beta^{t}\cdot\frac{d_{t}{}^{1-\gamma}}{1-\gamma}+\sum_{t}\lambda_{t}\bigg[(1-\tau_{H})w_{t}+(1-\tau_{K})r_{t}k_{t}+\delta_{K}\tau_{K}k_{t}+T_{t}-(k_{t+1}-(1-\delta_{K})k_{t})-p_{t}(1-\theta_{t})(d_{t+1}-(1-\delta)d_{t})\bigg]$

with~FOCs

$\bigg[d_{t}\bigg]\qquad\qquad\qquad\beta^{t}d_{t}^{-\gamma}+p_{t}(1-\theta_{t})(1-\delta)\lambda_{t}=p_{t-1}(1-\theta_{t-1})\lambda_{t-1}$

$\bigg[d_{t+1}\bigg]\qquad\qquad\qquad\beta^{t+1}d_{t+1}^{-\gamma}+p_{t+1}(1-\theta_{t+1})(1-\delta)\lambda_{t+1}=p_{t}(1-\theta_{t})\lambda_{t}$

$\bigg[k_{t+1}\bigg]\qquad\qquad\qquad\bigg[(1-\tau_{K})r_{t+1}+\delta_{K}\tau_{K}+(1-\delta_{K})\bigg]\lambda_{t+1}=\lambda_{t}\Rightarrow\Delta^{K}\lambda_{t+1}=\lambda_{t}$~

Use~$\bigg[k_{t+1}\bigg]$~to~solve~for~$\lambda_{t}$~in~both~\textrm{$\bigg[d_{t}\bigg],\bigg[d_{t+1}\bigg];$}

$\beta d_{t}^{-\gamma}+=\lambda_{t}[p_{t-1}(1-\theta_{t-1})\Delta_{-1}^{K}-p_{t}(1-\theta_{t})(1-\delta)];\quad\beta^{t+1}d_{t+1}^{-\gamma}=\lambda_{t}[p_{t}(1-\theta_{t})-p_{t+1}(1-\theta_{t+1})(1-\delta)/\Delta^{K}]$

and~divide~to~eliminate~$\lambda_{t}$~and~obtain

$d_{t}^{-\gamma}=\beta d_{t+1}^{-\gamma}\bigg[\frac{p_{t-1}(1-\theta_{t-1})\Delta_{-1}^{K}-p_{t}(1-\theta_{t})(1-\delta)}{p_{t}(1-\theta_{t})-p_{t+1}(1-\theta_{t+1})(1-\delta)/\Delta^{K}}\bigg]=\beta\Delta^{K}d_{t+1}^{-\gamma}\bigg[\frac{p_{t-1}(1-\theta_{t-1})\Delta_{-1}^{K}-p_{t}(1-\theta_{t})(1-\delta)}{p_{t}(1-\theta_{t})\Delta^{K}-p_{t+1}(1-\theta_{t+1})(1-\delta)}\bigg]$.

This~is~just~the~bracketed~expression~in~the~last~section,~with~$\alpha=0.$



\textbf{A~discrete~subsidy~shock~around~the~steady~state}

We~assume~house~price,~subsidy~and~the~rental~cost~of~capital~are~at

their~steady~state~values~$\overline{p},\overline{\theta},\text{\text{ and} }\overline{r}$respectively.~In~period~t+1,~the~subsidy

shifts~to~$\theta_{t+1}>\overline{\theta}$.~Hence

$\beta\Delta^{K}\frac{d_{t+1}^{-\gamma}}{d_{t}^{-\gamma}}=\bigg[\frac{\overline{p}(1-\overline{\theta)}\Delta^{K}-p_{t+1}(1-\theta_{t+1})(1-\delta)}{\overline{p}(1-\overline{\theta)}(\Delta^{K}-1+\delta)}\bigg]^{1+\alpha(\gamma-1)}$

If~r~and~p~are~sufficiently~inelastic~(or~exogenous),~the~numerator~is

a~higher~value~because~the~negative~term~in~it~decreases.~Hence~there

is~more~investment~in~durables.



\textbf{The~subsidy~point~elasticity~of~demand~around~the~steady~state}

Let~$G=\bigg[\frac{p_{t-1}(1-\theta_{t-1})\Delta_{-1}^{K}-p_{t}(1-\theta_{t})(1-\delta)}{p_{t}(1-\theta_{t})\Delta^{K}-p_{t+1}(1-\theta_{t+1})(1-\delta)}\bigg]$.~In~the~steady~state,~$G=1.$~However,

we~can~differentiate:

$\gamma\beta\Delta^{K}\bigg(\frac{\overline{d}}{\overline{d}}\bigg)^{\gamma-1}\frac{\partial d}{\partial\theta}=[1+\alpha(\gamma-1)]G^{\alpha(\gamma-1)}\cdot-\bigg[\overline{p}(1-\overline{\theta})\big(\Delta^{K}-1+\delta)\bigg]^{-1}\cdot(1-\delta)\bigg[-\frac{\partial p}{\partial d}\frac{\partial d}{\partial\theta}(1-\overline{\theta})+\overline{p}\bigg]$

Cancelling~out~terms,

$\gamma\beta\Delta^{K}\frac{\partial d}{\partial\theta}=[1+\alpha(\gamma-1)](1-\delta)\bigg[\overline{p}(1-\overline{\theta})\big(\Delta^{K}-1+\delta)\bigg]^{-1}\cdot\bigg[\frac{\partial p}{\partial d}\frac{\partial d}{\partial\theta}(1-\overline{\theta})-\overline{p}\bigg]$

$\Rightarrow\frac{\partial d}{\partial\theta}\bigg\{[1+\alpha(\gamma-1)](1-\delta)\bigg[\overline{p}\big(\Delta^{K}-1+\delta)\bigg]^{-1}\frac{\partial p}{\partial d}-\gamma\beta\Delta^{K}\bigg\}=[1+\alpha(\gamma-1)](1-\delta)\bigg[(1-\overline{\theta)}\big(\Delta^{K}-1+\delta)\bigg]^{-1}$

$\Rightarrow\frac{\partial d}{\partial\theta}=\frac{(1-\overline{\theta})^{-1}\big(\Delta^{K}-1+\delta){}^{-1}}{\bigg[\overline{p}\big(\Delta^{K}-1+\delta)\bigg]^{-1}\frac{\partial p}{\partial d}-\frac{\gamma\beta\Delta^{K}}{(1-\delta)(1+\alpha(\gamma-1))}}$

$\Rightarrow\frac{\partial d}{\partial\theta}=\frac{1}{1-\overline{\theta}}\cdot\frac{\big(\Delta^{K}-1+\delta)^{-1}}{[\overline{p}(\Delta^{K}-1+\delta)]^{-1}\big(\frac{\partial d}{\partial p}\big)^{-1}-\gamma\beta\frac{\Delta^{K}}{(1-\delta)(1+\alpha(\gamma-1))}}$.

Now~consider~the~percentage~change~in~housing~induced~by~the~subsidy:

$\frac{\partial d}{\partial\theta}\frac{1}{\overline{d}}=\frac{1}{1-\overline{\theta}}\cdot\frac{\big(\Delta^{K}-1+\delta)^{-1}}{\bigg[(\Delta^{K}-1+\delta)^{-1}\bigg(\frac{\partial d}{\partial p}\frac{\overline{p}}{\overline{d}}\bigg)^{-1}\overline{p}^{-1}-\gamma\beta\overline{d}\frac{\Delta^{K}}{(1-\delta)(1+\alpha(\gamma-1))}\bigg]}$

\emph{$\Rightarrow\frac{\partial d/\partial\theta(\overline{\theta})}{\overline{d}}=\frac{1}{1-\overline{\theta}}\cdot\bigg[[\epsilon_{\overline{d},p}(\overline{p})]^{-1}-(\overline{d})(\gamma/\nu_{2}\overline{p})(\beta\Delta^{K}\nu_{1})\bigg]^{-1},\qquad\nu_{1}=\overline{p}(\Delta^{K}-1+\delta),\nu_{2}=(1-\delta)(1+\alpha(\gamma-1)).$}

If~$\Delta^{K}\approx1-\delta(\text{e.g. }r+\delta\approx0)\text{ or }\nu_{2}\gg0,\frac{\partial d/\partial\theta}{\overline{d}}\approx\frac{1}{1-\overline{\theta}}\cdot\epsilon_{\overline{d},p}(\overline{p}).$

The~elasticity~is~$\epsilon_{\overline{d},\theta}(\overline{\theta})=\partial d/\partial\theta(\overline{\theta})\frac{\overline{\theta}}{\overline{d}}\approx\frac{\overline{\theta}}{1-\overline{\theta}}\cdot\epsilon_{\overline{d},p}(\overline{p}).$

Suppose~$\overline{\theta}=0$,~but~a~temporary~subsidy~$\theta'$~is~implemented~and~extended~long~enough

for~a~steady~state~$\overline{d}'$~to~be~reached.~Then~an~approximation~of~net~change~in

investment~upon~return~to~the~original~steady~state~can~be~proposed:

$\frac{\partial d/\partial\theta(\overline{\theta})}{\overline{d}}-\frac{\partial d/\partial\theta(\theta')}{\overline{d}'}=\frac{\epsilon_{\overline{d},p}(\overline{p})-\theta'\epsilon_{\overline{d},p}(\overline{p})-\epsilon_{\overline{d}',p}(p')}{1-\theta'}\approx(1+\theta')[\epsilon_{\overline{d},p}(\overline{p})-\theta'\epsilon_{\overline{d},p}(\overline{p})-\epsilon_{\overline{d}',p}(p')]$\end{lyxcode}

\end{document}
